news.title: So You Want to Start a Crypto Fund...
news.subtitle: There are many steps one has to take when starting a crypto fund that go well beyond raising capital and trading well. We talk about the service providers required by any new fund that wants to attract capital beyond family.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Your returns are crushing BTC. You were among the first yield farmers in Yearn, bought AXS the first day it was tradeable on Uniswap, and figured out that Sam Bankman-Fried was the next Warren Buffett.

Of course, your next logical move is to start a crypto fund. You have the track record, you have the edge, all you need is the outside capital to ensure you are the next Bobby Axelrod.

Yet there are many steps one has to take when starting a crypto fund that go well beyond raising capital and trading well. Service providers such as custodians, fund administrators, and lawyers are requirements for any new fund manager that wants to attract capital beyond their family.

For this post, we will discuss how these service providers operate within crypto, who the leading service providers in each category are, and the path emerging fund managers must take in order to successfully run a crypto fund as a business.

Custodian

More important than even a fund manager’s trading record, custodians play a significant role in the due diligence process for any allocator, from family office to pension fund. A custodian is a third party that ensures assets are being held securely. Fund managers' jobs are to generate alpha for their clients, which is a completely different business than ensuring the assets they manage are constantly secure from a technical perspective. Thus, legitimate allocators almost always require fund managers to work with third-party custodians, who specialize in the security of assets, before they allocate capital. Thus, once a fund manager expands beyond friends/family and suprasses $10 million AUM, they will likely need to work with a custodian to attract new capital.

Additionally, custodians act as a check on a manager’s ability to abscond with allocator’s capital, as they are the ones who hold the assets rather than the manager or the manager’s employees.

Custodians typically charge managers a percentage of the AUM stored with the custodian as a fee, though some charge transaction fees and/or withdrawal fees instead.

Historically, the leading custodians in crypto have been:

  • Gemini**
  • Bitgo (acquired by Galaxy Digital)
  • Coinbase Custody
  • Anchorage**
  • Kingdom Trust
  • Bakkt
  • Fidelity
  • PrimeTrust
  • Fireblocks*

While many of these custodians operate like traditional custodians, being a separate third party that securely holds assets on behalf of funds, others are using new blockchain native technology, such as Multi-Party Computation), to separate the private keys of assets and store them in multiple locations by multiple parties. In order to transfer funds, these multiple parties or a portion of these multiple parties must approve the transaction.

For those who have been in crypto for a while, MPC is like multi-sig functionality on steroids.

Interestingly, some custodians that utilize MPC argue that they never fully take custody of user’s funds, and thus do not need regulatory licenses, such as money transmitter license, since from their perspective MPC allows them to never solely custody funds. Additionally, they believe this exempts them from needing to be considered a qualified custodian.

The custody providers that are starred above rely solely on MPC, while the custody providers that are double starred use MPC in some form or fashion.

Fund Administrator

In addition to a custodian, all new funds will need to employ a fund administrator before taking on significant amounts of outside capital. A fund administrator, or fund admin for short, calculates the NAV and prepares reports that relate to the funds investment history. Furthermore, the fund admin is the one who prepares the fund’s financial statements. These reports are often distributed to LPs of the fund.

Additionally, just like other financial institutions, funds are required to perform KYC/AML for all allocators looking to invest in their fund. Usually, funds outsource this requirement to a fund admin.

Leading crypto fund administrators include:

  • MG Stover
  • Northern Trust
  • NAV Consulting
  • Theorem

Legal

Of course, in addition to the service providers above, all emerging fund managers should (though this isn’t legal advice!) retain a lawyer to assist in offering documents, fund structuring, and partnership agreements. Lawyers will help an emerging fund manager navigate whether the fund should be structured as a master-feeder fund, setting up an off-shore entity for non-US based allocators, and other questions that relate to the operations of the business.

Leading legal firms servicing crypto funds are:

  • Sidley
  • Cole-Frieman & Mallon
  • Sadis
  • Cooley

Auditor

Finally, emerging managers will want to engage with auditors in order to verify the validity of their track record and account statements. Often, the auditor will work closely with the fund admin when preparing reports.

Leading crypto fund auditors are:

  • Mazars
  • Akram
  • Richey May
  • Cohen & Co.
  • Lukka*
  • auditing report tech

MetaMask Institutional

We at Consensys recently launched MetaMask Institutional, a wallet built for institutions utilizing the same technology that supports the most battle-tested wallet in the industry, MetaMask, which boasts over 5 million monthly active users. MetaMask Institutional successfully bridges the gap between traditional finance and DeFi by connecting custodians and crypto funds— allowing funds to successfully access crypto native opportunities in a compliant way.

If you are interested in learning more, check out our website and follow us on twitter.

Explore MetaMask Institutional

nodes.title: 10 Things You Can Do with MetaMask Portfolio
nodes.subtitle: Whether you’re an OG or newbie, the Fox is here to make you more powerful in web3. Here are 10 things you can do today in MetaMask Portfolio.

image.title: 10 Things You Can Do with MetaMask Portfolio

childMarkdownRemark.html:
The MetaMask wallet has been around almost as long as web3 itself. Launched in 2016, the Fox has come a long way since then, guided by a mission to connect as many people around the world to the decentralized internet as possible. And we know connecting is just the start - much more than that MetaMask enables you to buy, sell, swap, bridge, stake, and beyond, and it all starts in Portfolio.

MetaMask Portfolio is where you get a clear, comprehensive view of your accounts and wallets across all networks. It’s also where your web3 journey begins. Whether you’ve been using MetaMask for years or even minutes, here are ten things you can do in Portfolio right now:

Ten ways MetaMask Portfolio makes you powerful in web3


1. Manage your digital assets and track performance in the dashboard: Easily view and manage all your digital assets including Ethereum tokens (ERC-20) and non-fungible tokens (NFTs), all from a single, unified interface. Keep an eye on your portfolio's performance over time, with insights into asset distribution, historical transactions, and overall value trends. Remember you can view the balances of any public Ethereum address or ENS. You can also view which airdrops you’re eligible for by using the claim airdrop feature.

How to use the Dashboard on MetaMask Portfolio:




2. Do your taxes: Yes, that’s correct – you can do your crypto taxes directly from Portfolio. All you have to do is connect your wallet and you’ll receive 10% off your tax services with recommended providers like CoinTracker, CoinLedger, ZenLedger, Crypto Tax Calculator, and Koinly:


3. Connect to dapps and explore web3: Access and engage with all the dapps web3 has to offer directly through Portfolio: from decentralized finance (DeFi) platforms like Aave, Uniswap, and Renzo, gaming dapps such as HyperPlay to NFT marketplaces like OpenSea.

4. Swap tokens: Use the built-in swap feature to trade tokens directly within Portfolio, leveraging the best available rates across multiple decentralized exchanges (DEXs).



5. Connect to multiple networks: Beyond Ethereum, MetaMask supports various Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM)-compatible networks, allowing users to switch between networks like Binance Smart Chain, Polygon, Linea, and more.

6. Buy and sell cryptocurrency: Buy cryptocurrencies directly within MetaMask Portfolio using traditional payment methods such as bank transfers or credit cards, and through integrations with third-party providers like Paypal and Revoult. And if you’re ready to sell, Portfolio has you covered, simply connect your wallet and select your method to cash out.




7. Integrate with your hardware wallet: Enhance your security by connecting MetaMask to hardware wallets like Ledger or Trezor from Portfolio, combining the convenience of MetaMask with the robust security of cold storage.

8. Customize privacy settings: Adjust your privacy settings to your preference, including setting up a custom RPC for specific networks, managing connected sites, and reviewing permissions. Learn more about how to configure your privacy settings here.

9. Participate in staking: Stake your crypto directly through MetaMask Portfolio, participating in the decision-making processes of various protocols and earning rewards. In Portfolio, there are three options for staking, Validator, Pooled, and Liquid. The below tutorials show you how easy it is to start staking based on your preference.




10. Bridge tokens: Bridging tokens on MetaMask refers to the process of transferring digital assets or tokens from one blockchain network to another using MetaMask as the interface for the transaction. Bridging tokens is a powerful feature in Portfolio that enhances the interoperability between different blockchain networks, enabling users to leverage the unique advantages of each network.


Coming soon in Portfolio


Transfer assets from centralized exchanges (CEXs) like Coinbase and Binance directly to your MetaMask wallet, or between different accounts within MetaMask itself, with enhanced security and ease. Stay tuned for this feature coming soon in Portfolio.

MetaMask Portfolio not only simplifies the management of digital assets but also opens up a world of possibilities for users to explore and engage with the decentralized ecosystem, all while maintaining a high level of security and user control. Get started today.

nodes.metaTitle: 10 Things You Can Do with MetaMask Portfolio
nodes.metaDescription: Whether you’re an OG or newbie, the Fox is here to make you more powerful in web3. Here are 10 things you can do today in MetaMask Portfolio.

nodes.title: MetaMask UI Update: Signature Redesign
nodes.subtitle: MetaMask Extension's new UI update makes reviewing signature requests simpler and clearer.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
We’re excited to introduce our latest UI update for MetaMask Extension, aimed at improving the readability of signature requests.

For All Users: Whether you're new to MetaMask or a seasoned user, you'll notice a fresh, more visually pleasing look when receiving signature requests. This update makes it easier to understand and review the actions you're about to approve.

How It Works: Starting with v12.2 of the MetaMask Extension, you'll see the redesigned interface for Permit and Sign In With Ethereum signatures. Don't worry if you don't see changes right away—we're rolling this out gradually to ensure a smooth transition.

In the coming months, we'll be extending this new UI to more signatures, transactions, and our Mobile app. Stay tuned for these updates!

To keep up with the latest on this rollout and other updates, follow us on Twitter @MetaMaskSupport and keep an eye on our Support Channel.

Want to Learn More? Dive deeper into the world of MetaMask signatures by checking out our support article.

Embrace clarity and enjoy peace of mind. Happy signing!

nodes.metaDescription: MetaMask Extension's new UI update makes reviewing signature requests simpler and clearer.

nodes.title: MetaMask UX Update: Improved Token Insights
nodes.subtitle: The new update provides a comprehensive understanding of your crypto assets with 24-hour percentage changes and detailed financial data per ERC20 token.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
We are excited to introduce two important enhancements to our token management feature:

  1. 24-Hour percentage changes in token lists
  2. Detailed financial data in token details

Your token lists will now display 24-hour percentage changes, allowing you to quickly assess price trends directly in MetaMask. You can also access detailed financial data, including price charts and market cap information, when you click on your ERC20 tokens.

This is now available in MetaMask Extension and is coming soon to Mobile.

The 24-hour percentage change will be visible in the main asset list view, while detailed financial data can be found by clicking on the specific ERC20 tokens.

Whether you're a seasoned investor or new to crypto, having easy access to price trends and detailed financial information helps you manage your portfolio more effectively. You can learn more about it in our support article.

Stay tuned for further updates. Enjoy!
